TI: A pilot longitudinal study of hippocampal volumes in pediatric maltreatment-related posttraumatic stress disorder.
AB: BACKGROUND: Adult posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is associated with decreased hippocampal volumes; however, decreased hippocampal volumes were not seen in pediatric maltreatment-related PTSD. We examined hippocampal volumes longitudinally to determine if a history of childhood traumatic stress alters hippocampal growth during puberty. METHODS: Magnetic resonance imaging was used to measure temporal lobes, amygdala, and hippocampal volumes in nine prepubertal maltreated subjects with pediatric maltreatment-related PTSD and nine sociodemographically matched healthy nonmaltreated yoked control subjects at baseline and after at least 2 years follow-up (during the later stages of pubertal development) using identical equipment and measurement methodology. RESULTS: Temporal lobe, amygdala and hippocampal volumes did not differ between groups at baseline, follow-up, or across time. CONCLUSIONS: Whereas these data are from a small sample, the results do not support hippocampal changes in pediatric maltreatment-related PTSD.
AD: University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Developmental Traumatology Neuroimaging Laboratory, Western Psychiatric Institute and Clinic, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania , USA.
